member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseChildControl.Key
member.summary: Identifier for custom action on client. That property will have priority over the Type or Act properties and will define the action which will occur on client. member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseChildControl.CssClass
member.summary: Gets or sets the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) class rendered by the Web server control on the client.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseToolbarButton.ImageName
member.summary: The name of the image displayed on the button.

remarks.p: This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.
This property is not used when WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode = ButtonMode.HTML.

WebHtmlEditor for .NET automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseToolbarButton.MouseOverImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the image displayed when the mouse is over the button.

remarks.p: Buttons will ALWAYS be provided with default values upon creation. See the Property Defaults topic for more information.
This property is only used when WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode = ButtonMode.ThreeStateImage. For information about the naming convention used for this property see Image Naming Convention.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseToolbarButton.MouseDownImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the image displayed when the user clicks the button with the mouse.

remarks.p: Buttons will ALWAYS be provided with default values upon creation. See the Property Defaults topic for more information.

This property is only used when WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode = ButtonMode.TwoStateImage or ButtonMode.ThreeStateImage. For information about the naming convention used for this property see Image Naming Convention.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BaseToolbarButton.FileType
member.summary: Gets or sets the file extention to be used for all image-related properties of the button.

remarks.p: The value of this property is combined with BaseToolbarItem.Act to derive the image-related property names. For example (using the default values for a "bold" button):

ul.li: FileType = ".gif"
ImageName = "bold.gif"
MouseOverImageName = "bold_over.gif"
MouseDownImageName = "bold_down.gif"

remarks.p: Using this example, if the FileType was changed to ".jpg", ImageName would return "bold.jpg" by default, MouseOverImageName would return "bold_over.jpg" by default, etc.

member.value: A string containing the file type to be used for all image-related properties. The default value is ".gif".

member.summary: Gets or sets the border color of the button when the mouse is placed over the button.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ClientSideEvents.BeforeAction
member.summary: Event fired before action occured.

remarks.p:
It can be the name of implemented function or explicit javascript statement(s). If the name of function is used, then that event handler may contain up to 8 parameters.
The reference to the JavaScript object that represents WebHtmlEditor.
The id of action. It can be equal to one of the values defined in the ActionType enum. In case of a custom button its value is equal to BaseChildControl.Key property.
The reference to the event object.
Possible extra parameters p4, p5, p6, p7, p8 and act may contain the caption, id of element, colors, etc.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ClientSideEvents.KeyDown
member.summary: Event fired when control receives the keydown event of browser.

remarks.p:
It can be the name of implemented function or explicit javascript statement(s). If the name of function is used, then that event handler may contain up to 3 parameters.
The reference to the JavaScript object that represents WebHtmlEditor.
The keyCode of event.
The reference to the event object.

Notes:
Event can be canceled by oEvent.cancel=true; but not all browsers will support that.
Postback can be triggered by oEvent.needPostBack=true;
Entry can be modified by oEvent.key=newKeyCode; but not all browsers will support that.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode
member.summary: Enumerates possible values for the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode property.

remarks.p: By default the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode property of the WebHtmlEditor is ButtonMode.Image, which specifies that a single image will represent each button and mouse-effects will be applied using DHTML (see the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonStyle property for more information on this). If you would like to use such highly-graphical button representations such as mouse-over image swaps set WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode to either ButtonMode.TwoStateImage (which specifies that there will be two images for each button, an "off" image and a "clicked" image) or ButtonMode.ThreeStateImage (which specifies that there will be three images for each button, an "off", an "over", and a "click" image). One of these two types will typically be used in skin implementations (see Using Skins) for more information. If you would like to remove images from the toolbr buttons altogether, set this property to ButtonMode.HTML and HTML input buttons will be used to represent the toolbar buttons.
Some image-name related properties will not have meaning depending on the button mode. For example:

ul.li: ImageName property - not used
MouseDownImageName property - not used
MouseOverImageName property - not used
ImageName property - represents the image used for the button (ex. "bold.gif")
MouseDownImageName property - not used
MouseOverImageName property - not used
ImageName property - represents the image used for the button (ex. "bold.gif")
MouseDownImageName property - represents the image used for the button when it is clicked (ex. "bold_down.gif")
MouseOverImageName property - not used
ImageName property - represents the image used for the button (ex. "bold.gif")
MouseDownImageName property - represents the image used for the button when it is clicked (ex. "bold_down.gif")
MouseOverImageName property - represents the image used for the button when the mouse is over the button (ex. "bold_over.gif")

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode.Image
member.summary: Single images will be used to represent buttons. Mouse-effects will be applied by changing the style of the image using DHTML.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode.TwoStateImage
member.summary: Two images will be used to represent each button ("off" and "down").

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode.ThreeStateImage
member.summary: Three images will be used to represent each button ("off", "over", and "down").

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode.HTML
member.summary: HTML buttons (input type='button') will be used to represent toolbar buttons.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType
member.summary: Enumerates the different ways the WebHtmlEditor can be rendered.

remarks.p: The WebHtmlEditor can be rendered multiple ways depending on the scenario. LayoutType.Standard renders a standard editor. LayoutType.Condensed renders a condensed editor (good for low-bandwidth scenarios). LayoutType.Skin renders a editor optimized for displaying graphical skins. NOTE! Changing from one layout type to another WILL change some property values. For example, if you are using the LayoutType.Standard layout, change the WebHtmlEditor.BackColor to red, then change the WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType to LayoutType.Skin, that property will be nulled out. For this reason, it is suggested that you always change the WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType FIRST, before making other changes, to eliminate any chances of a property being overwritten.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType.Standard
member.summary: The standard WebHtmlEditor layout.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType.Condensed
member.summary: Layout configured to use a condensed WebHtmlEditor, good for low bandwidth scenarios.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.LayoutType.Skin
member.summary: Layout configured for use with graphical skins.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BrowserType
member.summary: Enumerates the browser type as detected by the HTTP headers sent by the browser.

remarks.p: This property is used by the DetectedBrowserType of the WebHtmlEditor control. When a request is received, the WebHtmlEditor control attempts to autodetect the type of browser sending the request. The content sent to the browser depends on the value of this property.

Note, HTTP headers such as USER-AGENT are easily changed, which may cause the WebHtmlEditor control to incorrectly detect the browser type. If you require a more accurate detection mechanism, use a "proxy" page which does browser detection using client-side JavaScript before forwarding the request to the page that contains the WebHtmlEditor control. On the page that contains the WebHtmlEditor control, set the DetectedBrowserType property with the value you detected using your client-side script.

member.summary: The browser was detected to be Internet Explorer 5.5 or greater and is compatible with rich text editing.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BrowserType.CompatibleMozilla
member.summary: The browser was detected to be Mozilla 1.3 or greater and is compatible with rich text editing.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BrowserType.DownlevelIE
member.summary: The browser was detected to be lower than Internet Explorer 5.5 and is incompatible with rich text editing. Downlevel content will be rendered.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BrowserType.DownlevelMozilla
member.summary: The browser was detected to be lower than Mozilla 1.3 and is incompatible with rich text editing. Downlevel content will be rendered.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.BrowserType.Other
member.summary: The control was unable to successfully detect the browser type and it is assumed that the browser is incompatible with rich text editing. Downlevel content will be rendered.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor
member.summary: Replaces the TextBox control to provide advanced HTML editing within a browser.

remarks.p: The WebHtmlEditor control provides advanced HTML editing. The WebHtmlEditor control uses the MS DHTML engine to enable WYSIWYG-style editing within a browser. The WebHtmlEditor control renders an IFRAME, associated tables to provide an "editor" interface, and the necessary JavaScript to perform the editing actions.

Once a project is created, the WebHtmlEditor is provided with default display settings (for more information, see the WebHtmlEditor constructor topic). This default configuration can be modified one of two ways: Using the Properties Builder. Open the properties builder by right-clicking the WebHtmlEditor in the designer and choosing "Properties". This opens a configuration application which can be used to customize the look and configuration of the WebHtmlEditor.Using Code. Within code (such as in your code-behind page) the editor can easily be configured by setting properties and calling methods. For example, easily create a toolbar configuration by using the WebHtmlEditor.Clear method to clear the existing configuration and the WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem to quickly add new items to the toolbar. Look and feel of the editor can be easily customized as well. For example, to set the styles of all buttons, set the properties of the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonStyles object.
For more information about configuration, see the topic Configuring the Editor.

The WebHtmlEditor allows highly advanced customization, enabling a developer to create complex client-side objects such as custom windows-style dfialog boxes with only a few lines of code. For more information about this see the topic Advanced Customization.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.SaveSkin(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Save the current WebHtmlEditor configuration as an XML skin file.

remarks.p: This method saves the current WebHtmlEditor configuration as an XML skin file. Load the skin by using the WebHtmlEditor.LoadSkin method. For more information about creating and using skins, see Using Skins.

This method DOES NOT save information about individual toolbar items. For example, if you have changed the background color of a SINGLE button, this will not be persisted to the skin file. You must use the global properties for controlling style (such as the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonStyle property of WebHtmlEditor).

member.param: The filepath to which the XML file will be saved.
The name of the skin (for example "The Purple Skin"). This is used by the designer.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.LocalizationFile
member.summary: Gets or sets a value specifying a file path to an XML file specifying localization strings.
member.remarks:
Note: This property has priority over LocalizationType. If this property is set, then custom xml file is used instead of an embedded resource defined by the LocalizationType property. If value starts with ./, or /, or ~, then that value is used as it is, otherwise, the JavaScriptDirectory property is used as prefix.
Use this property only if the language translation you require is not included in the LocalizationType enumeration. You must create this XML file yourself, using the same XML format as the WebHtmlEditor file.
NOTE. When this property is set, all strings are cleared and reinitialized with the correct defaults language string. Any changes you made to child controls strings will be lost.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.LocalizationType
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines in what language strings are displayed

remarks.p: Note: The LocalizationFile has priority over this property. If LocalizationFile property is set, then custom xml file is used instead of an embedded resource defined by this property.

All predefined strings are sourced from an embedded XML resource file. Changing the value of this property will cause all predefined strings to be translated into the selected language. For example if the current LocalizationType is English, and French is chosen, the string "Color" becomes "Couleur".
NOTE. When this property is set, all strings are cleared and reinitialized with the correct defaults language string. Any changes you made to child controls strings will be lost.

Use the TextArea if the user can continue with a comaptible browser. In this case, a standard HTML TEXTAREA will be displayed to the user, allowing them to enter plain text.

member.value: A DownlevelTextArea control representing the textarea rendered to the user.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.JavaScriptDirectory
member.summary: Directory where client-script js files are located.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets a virtual, relative, or absolute pathname of the directory containing all of the images used by the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: WebHtmlEditor for .NET automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example (using WebHtmlEditor.BackgroundImageName as an example), if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and the WebHtmlEditor.BackgroundImageName property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If the WebHtmlEditor.BackgroundImageName property was set to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string representing the virtual, relative, or absolute pathname of the directory containing all of the images used by the WebHtmlEditor. The default value is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/".

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.UploadedFilesDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets a virtual, relative, or absolute pathname of the directory where all files are uploaded.

remarks.p: This property impacts all ToolbarUploadButton controls on the toolbar. Each ToolbarUploadButton has a ToolbarUploadButton.Upload property representing the upload dialog that will be displayed to the user when the button is clicked. The user can use this dialog to upload files. This upload dialog, by default, will upload files to the directory specified by this property. If you have multiple ToolbarUploadButton controls on the toolbar, they will all upload to this directory by default. If you want to change this so multiple ToolbarUploadButton controls upload to different directories, you must do this on the ToolbarUploadButton level instead of setting this property, which acts globally.

member.value: A string representing the virtual, relative, or absolute pathname of the directory where all files uploaded using the WebHtmlEditor are stored. The default value is "/ig_common/upload".

remarks.p: If editing web pages, set this property to the url of the eventual destination of the page.

member.value: A string value representing the base path value for url conversions.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.UrlType
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines how links are represented in the editor.

remarks.p: Some browsers improperly convert urls within the editor. For example, IE will convert the following link:
to
which results in a broken link. TextBox for ASP.NET automatically converts these improper links to a proper link. This property controls how these links are converted.

member.value: A UrlType value. The default value is UrlType.RootRelative.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.BackgroundImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the background image to display as the background of the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: This property is only indended to be used if you are applying a highly graphical skin to the WebHtmlEditor. For more information about skin creation and usage, see the topic Using Skins.

WebHtmlEditor for .NET automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.IsPostbackFromUpload
member.summary: Gets a value specifying if the current page request was due to a postback from an HtmlBoxUpload control.

remarks.p: The WebHtmlEditor control may have one or many instances of a ToolbarUploadButton on the toolbar. This button launches an "upload" dialog which can be used to upload files to the server via a post request. Use this property to check if the postback to the page was due to an "upload" postback, instead of a standard postback (triggered by a button click, for example).

member.value: True if the current request was a postback from an HtmlBoxUpload control, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.StartupMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a StartupMode value indicating the startup mode of the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: Set this property to StartupMode.HTML to start the WebHtmlEditor in HTML mode.

member.value: An StartupMode value indicating the startup mode of the WebHtmlEditor. The default value is StartupMode.Design

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.TabStrip
member.summary: Gets a HtmlBoxTabStrip object representing the tabstrip used by the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: This object represents the "Design/HTML" tab strip at the bottom of the WebHtmlEditor. Set the properties of this object to change the visual representation of the tabstrip.

member.value: The HtmlBoxTabStrip object representing the tabstrip used by the WebHtmlEditor.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar
member.summary: Gets an HtmlBoxToolbar control representing the toolbar.

remarks.p: The Toolbar contains/manages all toolbar items. Only classes that derive from BaseToolbarItem can be placed on the toolbar. The following list describes each class that derives from BaseToolbarItem: ToolbarButton - Represents a standard formatting button.ToolbarDialogButton - Represents a button which launches a dialog.ToolbarUploadButton - Represents a button which launches a file upload dialog.ToolbarMenuButton - Represents a button which launches a menu.ToolbarImage - Represents an image on the toolbar.ToolbarText - Represents text on the toolbar.

The HtmlBoxToolbar.Items property exposes the ToolbarItemCollection which contains/manages all toolbar items. Use the WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem method as a shortcut method to easily add a new toolbar item. The ToolbarItemCollection.Clear method of the ToolbarItemCollection and the WebHtmlEditor.Clear method of the WebHtmlEditor both clear this collection.

member.value: An HtmlBoxToolbar control representing the toolbar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.ProgressBar
member.summary: Gets the HtmlBoxProgressBar representing the progressbar used for the WebHtmlEditor preload, if it is enabled.

remarks.p: If the progress bar is enabled (by setting HtmlBoxProgressBar.Visble to true) progress will be displayed while the editor is loading. Progress is automatically incremented each time a new graphic is loaded. The default WebHtmlEditor settings are very light graphically and, as such, there is little benefit in using a progress bar. A good scenario for using the progress bar would be in the case of a highly-graphical editor in a low-bandwidth scenario.
The progress bar is only displayed on the initial load. For any subsequent loads resulting from postback the progress bar is not displayed.

member.value: An HtmlBoxProgressBar representing the progressbar used for the WebHtmlEditor preload.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.RightClickMenu
member.summary: Gets an HtmlBoxMenu control representing the right-click menu displayed when the user right-clicks on the WebHtmlEditor with the mouse.

remarks.p: The default right-click menu (used when the WebHtmlEditor.RightClickBehavior property is RightClickBehavior.HtmlBoxMenu) is a context sensitive right-click menu tightly coupled with the WebHtmlEditor. For example, when the user right-clicks within a table, they are presented with table specific options such as "Table Properties" and "Cell Properties".
Style changes to the global WebHtmlEditor.MenuStyle object are applied to the WebHtmlEditor.RightClickMenu.

member.value: An WebHtmlEditor control representing the right-click menu displayed when the user right-clicks on the WebHtmlEditor with the mouse.

remarks.p: Set the properties of this object to change the visual representation of the text window. For example, set the HtmlBoxTextWindow.Transparent property to cause the text window to be transparent. Set the HtmlBoxTextWindow.BackgroundImage property to place a backround image on the text window.

member.value: An HtmlBoxTextWindow control representing the actual editing window of the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: The default value displays a "Windows-style" right-click menu which is tightly coupled with the WebHtmlEditor. Set this property to RightClickBehavior.WindowsMenu to display the standard Windows menu. Set this property to RightClickBehavior.None to suppress all menus.

remarks.p: Depending on the scenario, you may or may not want the WebHtmlEditor to receive the mouse focus. For example, if the WebHtmlEditor is the only control on the page, you probably want it to receive the mouse focus. If the WebHtmlEditor is one of many form controls on the page, you may not want the WebHtmlEditor to receive the mouse focus.

member.summary: Gets a ButtonStyle object representing the style that will be applied to all classes derived from BaseToolbarButton on the toolbar.

remarks.p: Use this object to globally apply styles to all buttons at once. For example, setting ButtonStyle.BackColor to Color.Red will cause all of the buttons to have a red background.

If WebHtmlEditor.ButtonMode is ButtonMode.Image (the default), the WebHtmlEditor.ButtonStyle property can be used to apply visual "mouse effects" to buttons. For example, setting ButtonStyle.MouseOverBackColor to Color.Blue will cause all of the buttons to turn blue when the mouse is placed over them.
If you want one (or many) buttons to have a different style than the rest, you can set the style properties on the button level instead of using this global style mechanism.

member.summary: Raised when a postback is raised by a toolbar button click.

remarks.p: A ToolbarButton can raise a postback if it's ToolbarButton.RaisePostback property is true. When this occurs, the ToolbarClick will be raised. A ToolbarClickEventArgs object will be passed into this event. This object will include a ToolbarClickEventArgs.Button property which encapsulates the button which was clicked.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.WebHtmlEditor.Controls
member.summary: Gets a ControlCollection object that represents the child controls for a specified server control in the UI hierarchy.

remarks.p: On an ASP.NET page, when controls are added declaratively between the opening and closing tags of a server control, ASP.NET automatically adds the controls to the containing server control's ControlCollection. Any HTML tags or text strings that are not processed on the server are treated as LiteralControl objects. These are added to the collection like other server controls.

The Controls property allows you programmatic access to the instance of the ControlCollection class for any server control. You can add controls to the collection, remove controls from the collection, or iterate through the server controls in the collection.

member.value: The collection of child controls for the specified server control.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog
member.summary: Represents a dialog.

remarks.p: A single instance of HtmlBoxDialog object is tied to each instance of ToolbarDialogButton on the toolbar. When a button of this type is clicked, the dialog represented by the HtmlBoxDialog objectis displayed.
There are two scenarios for creating/using dialogs:

ul.li: Predefined dialogs: These types of dialogs are tied to predefined toolbar buttons. For example, if you add a ToolbarDialogButton with a ToolbarDialogButton.Type == ToolbarDialogButtonType.FindReplace, a predefined find/replace HtmlBoxDialog will be tied to the ToolbarDialogButton (and exposed as the ToolbarDialogButton.Dialog property). Typically, you won't want want to modify the actual content of the dialog, but instead would modify the look and feel of the dialog using properties such as BackColor or TitlebarBackColor.

Custom dialogs: These types of dialogs are tied to custom toolbar buttons. For example, if you add a ToolbarDialogButton with a ToolbarDialogButton.Type == ToolbarDialogButtonType.Custom, an WebHtmlEditor dialog would be tied to the ToolbarDialogButton (and exposed as the ToolbarDialogButton.Dialog property). However, this dialog would be empty until some content was supplied for the dialog. This is done by using the HtmlBoxDialog.Text property.

member.summary: Gets or sets a collection of strings used in the dialog.

This collection is useful if you wish to modify the strings used within predefined dialogs. For example, if you would like to change the text on the "Cancel" button to say "Close", you could do the following:

This is especially useful in scenarios where you need to localize the WebHtmlEditor to a non-English language. See the topic Localizing the WebHtmlEditor for more information and for a list of keys used for each Strings collection associated with each predefined dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog.ExternalFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the url of an external file containing the content for the dialog.

remarks.p: This property is not used by any of the predefined dialogs used by the WebHtmlEditor. However, you may set this property if you would like to supply the content for the dialog from a file on the server. If this is the case, the dialog will launch in a modal dialog box that you will not be able to modify the titlebar properties (such as TitlebarBackColor) of.

member.value: A string representing a url of an external file containing the content for the dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog.DialogContentID
member.summary: Gets or sets the client-side id of the HTML element containing the content for the dialog.

remarks.p: If this dialog is a predefined HtmlBoxDialog (which is the case for all HtmlBoxDialogs that are created within the component) this property references a hidden HTML element that contains the content for the dialog. Do not change this value for predefined dialogs, as the dialog will not work. If you are creating a custom dialog, it is recommended to use the HtmlBoxDialog.Text property instead of this property to supply the content for the dialog, although this property may be used.

member.value: A string representing the client-side id of the HTML element containing the content for the dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog.Type
member.summary: Gets or sets the display type of the WebHtmlEditor dialog.

remarks.p: If this property is DialogType.InternalWindowWithTitlebar, the dialog will be a "Windows-style" dialog, complete with titlebar. This type of dialog is draggable with the mouse. If this property is InternalWindow, the dialog will be a titlebar-less panel which is non-draggable. This property only needs to be set for custom dialog implementations, as in predefined dialogs this property will already be configured to the appropriate value for the dialog.

member.value: A DialogType value specifying the display type of the WebHtmlEditor dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog.TitlebarImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the image name of the titlebar image.

remarks.p: This property supplies an image name which is used as a dialog "icon" in the upper left corner of the dialog. This property is only used when the HtmlBoxDialog.Type property = DialogType.InternalWindowWithTitlebar.

This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string representing the image name of the titlebar image.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxDialog.TitlebarXImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the image name of the titlebar X (close window) image.

remarks.p: This property supplies an image name which is used as a close window image in the upper right corner of the dialog. This property is only used when the HtmlBoxDialog.Type property = DialogType.InternalWindowWithTitlebar.

This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string representing the image name of the titlebar X (close window) image.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxMenu
member.summary: Represents a menu.

remarks.p: A single instance of HtmlBoxMenu object is tied to each instance of ToolbarMenuButton on the toolbar. When a button of this type is clicked, the menu represented by the HtmlBoxMenu object is displayed. In addition, another instance of HtmlBoxMenu is used to represent the right-click menu (exposed by the WebHtmlEditor.RightClickMenu property) which is displayed when the user right-clicks on the WebHtmlEditor.
There are two scenarios for creating/using menus:

ul.li: Predefined menus: These types of menus are either tied to predefined toolbar buttons or are used as the right-click menu. For example, if you add a ToolbarDialogButton with a ToolbarMenuButton.Type == ToolbarMenuButtonType.InsertTable, a predefined table formatting HtmlBoxMenu will be tied to the ToolbarMenuButton (and exposed as the ToolbarMenuButton.Menu property). Typically, you won't want want to modify the actual content of the menu, but instead would modify the look and feel of the menu using properties such as BackColor or ImageColumnColor.

Custom menus: These types of menus are tied to custom toolbar buttons. For example, if you add a ToolbarMenuButton with a ToolbarMenuButton.Type == ToolbarMenuButtonType.Custom, an HtmlBoxMenu would be tied to the ToolbarMenuButton (and exposed as the ToolbarMenuButton.Menu property). However, this menu would be empty until some content was supplied for the menu. This is done by adding items to the ToolbarMenuButton.Menu.Items collection.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxMenuItem
member.summary: Represents a single menu item on an HtmlBoxMenu.

remarks.p: There are two types of HtmlBoxMenuItem objects. The standard type calls a client-side JavaScript function. Create an HtmlBoxMenuItem of this type by using the HtmlBoxMenuItem(string,string,string) constructor. The dialog type launches an HtmlBoxDialog object. Create an HtmlBoxMenuItem of this type by using the HtmlBoxMenuItem(string,string,HtmlBoxDialog constructor).

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxMenuItemCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection used to manage HtmlBoxMenuItems.

remarks.p: When the WebHtmlEditor creates this collection internally, it provides a reference to the HtmlBoxMenu web control that is the "parent" of this collection. When items are added/removed to the collection, references to these items are also added/removed to the ASP.NET web control heirarchy. For this reason, it is NOT recommended that you create an object of this type within your code. Simply used the instance already created and initialized, and exposed as the HtmlBoxMenu.Items property of the HtmlBoxMenu control.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxProgressBar
member.summary: Represents a progress bar displayed while the WebHtmlEditor is loading.

remarks.p: If the progress bar is enabled (by setting HtmlBoxProgressBar.Display to true, progress will be displayed while the editor is loading. Progress is automatically incremented each time a new graphic is loaded. The default WebHtmlEditor settings are very light graphically and, as such, there is little benefit in using a progress bar. A good scenario for using the progress bar would be in the case of a highly-graphical editor in a low-bandwidth scenario.
The progress bar is only displayed on the initial load. For any subsequent loads resulting from postback the progress bar is not displayed.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxTextWindow.BackgroundImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets a value specifying the image name to display within the editing window.

remarks.p: When this property is set, an image is displayed on the background of the editing surface. This image does not interfere with editing. Typing occurs "over" the image. This is a useful property to use if you would like to set a watermark for the editor.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode
member.summary: Enumerates the different types of file uploads.

remarks.p: This enumeration effects the way HtmlBoxUpload controls are rendered.

member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is configured to handle images.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode.File
member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is configured to handle text/html files (such as .htm, .html, .asp files).

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode.Flash
member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is configured to handle Macromedia Flash files.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode.Upload
member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is configured to be a generic file uploader.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode.WindowsMedia
member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is configured to handle Windows Media Player compatible files.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.UploadMode.None
member.summary: The HtmlBoxUpload is not yet configured.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload
member.summary: Represents a dialog used to upload/browse for files.

remarks.p: This control is attached to a ToolbarUploadButton (as the ToolbarUploadButton.Upload property). When a button of this type is clicked, the upload dialog represented by the attached HtmlBoxUpload control is displayed. This dialog is used to upload local files to the server, and to browse for and load files from the server onto the editor.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of HtmlBoxUpload

remarks.p: The default constructor creates and initializes a default instance of HtmlBoxUpload.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.Caption
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that is displayed as the dialog caption.

remarks.p: This property is only used when the HtmlBoxDialog.Type = DialogType.InnerWindowWithTitlebar.

member.value: A string representing the text that is displayed as the dialog caption.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.AllowDownwardBrowsing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which indicates if downward browsing is enabled.

remarks.p: When this property is true, the user is allowed to browse down (into subdirectories) of the WebHtmlEditor.InitialDirectory.

member.value: true if the user is allowed to browse downward from the InitialDirectory; false otherwise. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.AllowDelete
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which indicates if the user is able to delete files.

remarks.p: When this property is true, a delete link is displayed next to each file in the dialog. The user can click this link to delete the file.

member.value: true if the user is allowed to delete files; false otherwise. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.UseRelativePaths
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines if relative paths are used for A and IMG tags.

remarks.p: The IFRAME object automatically makes all paths absolute. When this value is set to true, these absolute paths will be fixed to be relative, for example a link like "http://myserver/myimages/blah.gif" might be turned into "../myimages/blah.gif".

member.value: true if relative paths should be fixed, false otherwise. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.ExternalFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the url of an external file containing the content for the dialog.

remarks.p: This property is not used by any of the predefined dialogs used by the WebHtmlEditor. However, you may set this property if you would like to supply the content for the dialog from a file on the server. If this is the case, the dialog will launch in a modal dialog box that you will not be able to modify the titlebar properties (such as TitlebarBackColor) of.

member.value: A string representing a url of an external file containing the content for the dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.UploadEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if the user is allowed to upload files.

remarks.p: Setting this property to false will cause the upload portion of the upload dialog to not be rendered, causing the upload dialog to be a read-only mechanism for loading images/files into the editor window.

member.value: true if the user is allowed to upload files; false otherwise. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.FileImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the image name to use for the "file" icon.

remarks.p: This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

remarks.p: This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.InitialDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial directory of the file browser.

remarks.p: Each upload dialog instance has a file browser associated with it which displays files on the server. This property sets the directory which the file browser is initialized to when the upload is first displayed. Any files uploaded will be stored in this directory. This property gets it's initial value from the WebHtmlEditor.UploadedFiles property.

member.value: A string representing the initial directory of the file browser.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.MaxFileSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum file size (in bytes) that the server will accept when uploading files.

remarks.p: If a user attempts to upload a size larger than the value specified here, the file will not be accepted and an error message will be displayed. Set this property to 0 to accept any files. Set the HtmlBoxUpload.UploadEnabled property to false to completely disable file upload.

member.value: The maximum file size (in bytes) that will be accepted by the server when uploading files. The default value is 1048576.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.FileTypeMustMatchFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which indicates if file types not matching the current Filter are accepted.

remarks.p: The HtmlBoxUpload.Filter property specifies the types of files displayed in the "file browser" of the upload. If this property is true, all uploaded files will be compared to the WebHtmlEditor.Filter property. If the file type does not match, the file is not uploaded and an error message is displayed.

member.value: true if only file types matching the current filter are accepted; false if any file types are accepted. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode of the upload dialog.

remarks.p: When this property is UploadMode.Image, the upload dialog will come preconfigured to display and load images into the editor window. When this property is UploadMode.File, the upload dialog will come preconfigured to displaye and load files (such as .htm files) into the editor window.

member.value: An UploadMode value indicating the mode of the upload dialog; the default value is UploadMode.Image.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.Filter
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter used for displaying files in the file browser.

remarks.p: The format of the filter is a comma delimited list of file types (ex "*.gif,*.jpg,*.bmp"). The filter is also used by the HtmlBoxUpload.FileTypeMustMatchFilter property, which controls whether or not file types that do not match the filter are uploaded.

member.value: A string representing the current file filter. The default value is "*.gif,*.jpg,*.bmp".

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.HtmlBoxUpload.Strings
member.summary: Gets or sets a collection of strings used in the dialog.

remarks.p: For predefined dialogs, this collection will contain a list of strings used within the dialog. For custom dialogs, this collection is not used. This collection is useful if you wish to modify the strings used within predefined dialogs. For example, if you would like to change the text on the "Cancel" button to say "Close", you could do the following:

This is especially useful in scenarios where you need to localize the WebHtmlEditor to a non-English language. See the topic Localizing the WebHtmlEditor for more information and for a list of keys used for each Strings collection associated with each predefined dialog.

member.value: A StringValueCollection collection representing the strings to be used in the dialog.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar
member.summary: Represents the toolbar of the WebHtmlEditor.

remarks.p: There is one Toolbar instance associated with each WebHtmlEditor (as the WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar property). Configure the Toolbar by adding items derived from BaseToolbarItem (ToolbarButton, ToolbarDropDown, ToolbarImage, ToolbarMenuButton, ToolbarText, and ToolbarUploadButton). This can be done using the easy-to-use high level WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem method of the WebHtmlEditor control, or by using the Toolbar.Items collection (i.e., calling' WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add, WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Remove, etc).

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarButton
member.summary: Represents a button that performs standard formatting.

remarks.p: The ToolbarButton control represents a button that performs standard formatting (formatting which occurs without any other dialogs or menus). A ToolbarButton can be created and used one of two ways:

ul.li: Calling WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem, passing in a ToolbarItemType associated with ToolbarButton (such as ToolbarItemType.Bold) creates the ToolbarButton, initializing it with default values for the "bold" type, and adds it to the Toolbar in one step.

Create a new ToolbarButton, passing in a ToolbarButtonType (such as ToolbarButtonType.Bold). This will create and initialize the ToolbarButton with default values for the "bold" type. Add the ToolbarButton using the ToolbarItemCollection.Add method (WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add).

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarButton.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a custom ToolbarButton

remarks.p: The default constructor creates and initializes a ToolBarButton as a ToolbarButtonType.Custom button.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarButton.#ctor(Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarButtonType)
member.summary: Creates a predefined ToolbarButton

remarks.p: This constructor creates a ToolbarButton of the specified type and supplies it with the default values for the specified type. For example, if type == ToolbarButtonType.Bold, the properties would be as follows:

ul.li: ToolbarButton.ImageName = "bold.gif"
etc...

member.param: The ToolbarButtonType which is used to supply the proper default properties for the ToolbarButton.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarButton.RaisePostback
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which indicates the ToolbarButton will initiate a server postback when clicked.

remarks.p: The ToolbarButtonType.Save type is the only button type that sets this property to true by default. If this property is true, the ToolbarButton will cause a postback to the server when clicked. The WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarClick event will be raised when this is detected. A ToolbarEventArgs object will be passed into the event handler, making the ToolbarButton control responsible for the event available to the event handler.

member.value: true if the button initiates a server postback when clicked; false otherwise.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDialogButton
member.summary: Represents a button that raises a dialog.

remarks.p: The ToolbarDialogButton control represents a button that raises a dialog. This may be a non-draggable "panel" (such as with a "font-color" dialog, created by using the ToolbarDialogButtonType.FontColor value) or a fully-interactive, draggable "window" (such as with "insert horizontal rule" created by using the ToolbarDialogButtonType.InsertRule value).
The dialog that appears when the ToolbarDialogButton is clicked is represented by an HtmlBoxDialog, exposed by the ToolbarDialogButton.Dialog property.
A ToolbarDialogButton can be created and used one of two ways:

ul.li: Calling WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem, passing in a ToolbarItemType associated with ToolbarDialogButton (such as ToolbarItemType.FontColor) creates the ToolbarDialogButton, initializing it with default values for the "font color" type, and adds it to the Toolbar in one step.

Create a new ToolbarDialogButton, passing in a ToolbarDialogButtonType (such as ToolbarDialogButtonType.FontColor). This will create and initialize the ToolbarDialogButton with default values for the "font color" type. Add the ToolbarDialogButton using the ToolbarItemCollection.Add method (WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDialogButton.Dialog
member.summary: Returns the HtmlBoxDialog associated with this ToolbarDialogButton.

remarks.p: This property returns the HtmlBoxDialog representing the dialog that appears when the ToolbarDialogButton is clicked. For all predefined ToolbarDialogButtons (all ToolbarDialogButtonType values except for ToolbarDialogButtonType.Custom) this property will be properly initialized. For ToolbarDialogButtonType.Custom, create the dialog content by setting the HtmlBoxDialog.Text property.

member.value: The HtmlBoxDialog associated with the ToolbarDialogButton.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDialogButton.Controls
member.summary: Gets a ControlCollection object that represents the child controls for a specified server control in the UI hierarchy.

remarks.p: On an ASP.NET page, when controls are added declaratively between the opening and closing tags of a server control, ASP.NET automatically adds the controls to the containing server control's ControlCollection. Any HTML tags or text strings that are not processed on the server are treated as LiteralControl objects. These are added to the collection like other server controls.

The Controls property allows you programmatic access to the instance of the ControlCollection class for any server control. You can add controls to the collection, remove controls from the collection, or iterate through the server controls in the collection.

member.value: The collection of child controls for the specified server control.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDropDown
member.summary: Represents a drop-down select box.

remarks.p: The ToolbarDropDown control represents a drop-down select box. On the control level, each ToolbarDropDown is made up of ToolbarDropDownItems (accessable via the ToolbarDropDown.Items property). When creating predefined ToolbarDropDown types (all ToolbarDropDownTypes besides ToolbarDropDownType.Custom) the ToolbarDropDown will be created with the proper default calues for the type.
A ToolbarDropDown can be created and used one of two ways:

ul.li: Calling WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem, passing in a ToolbarItemType associated with ToolbarDropDown (such as ToolbarItemType.FontName) creates the ToolbarDropDown, initializing it with default values for the "font name" type, and adds it to the Toolbar in one step.

Create a new ToolbarDropDown, passing in a ToolbarDropDownType (such as ToolbarDropDownType.FontName). This will create and initialize the ToolbarDropDown with default values for the "font name" type. Add the ToolbarDropDown using the ToolbarItemCollection.Add method (WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDropDown.ImageName
member.summary: The name of the image displayed as the drop-down arrow.

remarks.p: This property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarDropDown.UseAdvancedDisplay
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which indicates if advanced drop-down displays should be used.

remarks.p: This property only has effect on the predefined drop-down types ToolbarDropDownType.FontFormatting, ToolbarDropDownType.FontName, and ToolbarDropDownType.FontStyle. If this property is true, advanced displays are used. For example, in the case of ToolbarDropDownType.FontName, the font name will be displayed using the actual font. Set this property to false to have the drop-down look like a standard, non-formatted drop-down.

member.value: true if advanced display should be used; false otherwise. The default value is true.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarImage
member.summary: Represents a non-interactive image on the toolbar.

remarks.p: Create a custom ToolbarImage to insert your own image onto the toolbar or use a predefined ToolbarImage type to apply formatting to your toolbar such as item seperators and row seperators.
A ToolbarImage can be created and used one of two ways:

ul.li: Calling WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem, passing in a ToolbarItemType associated with ToolbarImage (such as ToolbarItemType.Seperator) creates the ToolbarImage, initializing it with default values for the "seperator" type, and adds it to the Toolbar in one step.

Create a new ToolbarImage, passing in a ToolbarImageType (such as ToolbarImageType.Seperator). This will create and initialize the ToolbarImage with default values for the "seperator" type. Add the ToolbarImage using the ToolbarItemCollection.Add method (WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarImage.ImageName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the image displayed on the toolbar.

remarks.p: For preset types, this property will come preset to a valid imagename found in the images directory (specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory) created during the product installation. Set this property only if you wish to change from the presets or if you are creating a custom ToolbarImage.

WebHtmlEditor automatically assumes that all images are in the directory specified by WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory. For example, if the value of WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory is "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/" (the default) and this property was set to "myimage.jpg", the control would assume the file can be found at "/ig_common/images/htmleditor/myimage.jpg". If you set this property to a string that has some form of directory designation, such as "slashes" within it (for example "C:\temp\myimage.jpg") the control would no longer assume that the image is within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory but would use the full path you supplied for this property.

member.value: A string containing no instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a image file contained within WebHtmlEditor.ImageDirectory or a string containing one or many instances of "/", "\", or "~" indicating a full virtual, relative, or absolute path to an image file. The default value is an empty string.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarImage.Type
member.summary: Gets or sets the ToolbarImageType associated with this ToolbarImage.

remarks.p: Typically, this property gets it's value during initialization. However, this property can be set. If this occurs, the current values of the ToolbarImage will be lost and replaced with the default settings associated with the new ToolbarImageType.

member.value: A ToolbarImageType associated with this ToolbarImage.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarItemCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection used to manage BaseToolbarItem controls.

remarks.p: When the WebHtmlEditor creates this collection internally, it provides a reference to the Toolbar web control that is the "parent" of this collection. When items are added/removed to the collection, references to these items are also added/removed to the ASP.NET web control heirarchy. For this reason, it is NOT recommended that you create an object of this type within your code. Simply used the instance already created and initialized, and exposed as the Toolbar.Items property of the Toolbar control.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarMenuButton
member.summary: Represents a button that opens a menu.

remarks.p: The ToolbarMenuButton control represents a button that opens a menu. For example, if the ToolbarMenuButton.Type is ToolbarMenuButtonType.InsertTable, the button will open a menu used to create and format a table.
The menu that appears when the ToolbarMenuButton is clicked is represented by an HtmlBoxMenu, exposed by the ToolbarMenuButton.Menu property.
A ToolbarMenuButton can be created and used one of two ways:

ul.li: Calling WebHtmlEditor.AddToolbarItem, passing in a ToolbarItemType associated with ToolbarMenuButton (such as ToolbarItemType.InsertTable) creates the ToolbarMenuButton, initializing it with default values for the "insert table" type, and adds it to the Toolbar in one step.

Create a new ToolbarMenuButton, passing in a ToolbarMenuButtonType (such as ToolbarMenuButtonType.InsertTable). This will create and initialize the ToolbarMenuButton with default values for the "insert table" type. Add the ToolbarMenuButton using the ToolbarItemCollection.Add method (WebHtmlEditor.Toolbar.Items.Add).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarMenuButton.Controls
member.summary: Gets a ControlCollection object that represents the child controls for a specified server control in the UI hierarchy.

remarks.p: On an ASP.NET page, when controls are added declaratively between the opening and closing tags of a server control, ASP.NET automatically adds the controls to the containing server control's ControlCollection. Any HTML tags or text strings that are not processed on the server are treated as LiteralControl objects. These are added to the collection like other server controls.

The Controls property allows you programmatic access to the instance of the ControlCollection class for any server control. You can add controls to the collection, remove controls from the collection, or iterate through the server controls in the collection.

member.value: The collection of child controls for the specified server control.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebHtmlEditor.ToolbarUploadButton.Controls
member.summary: Gets a ControlCollection object that represents the child controls for a specified server control in the UI hierarchy.

remarks.p: On an ASP.NET page, when controls are added declaratively between the opening and closing tags of a server control, ASP.NET automatically adds the controls to the containing server control's ControlCollection. Any HTML tags or text strings that are not processed on the server are treated as LiteralControl objects. These are added to the collection like other server controls.

The Controls property allows you programmatic access to the instance of the ControlCollection class for any server control. You can add controls to the collection, remove controls from the collection, or iterate through the server controls in the collection.

member.value: The collection of child controls for the specified server control.
